Sec. 103-1. - Uniform rules of the road adopted; penalty. (a) Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 40-6-372, O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1 and O.C.G.A § 40-6-1 through O.C.G.A. § 40-6-397, known as "Uniform Rules of the Road", are hereby adopted as and for the traffic regulations of the City of Waynesboro, Georgia, with like effect as if recited in full herein. (b) Unless another penalty is expressly provided by law, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-8. (Ord. No. 2016-02-02, § 2, 3-21-2016) Sec. 103-2. - Pedestrians interfering with traffic. Pedestrians shall not interfere with the proper use of the public streets, roads and alleys. (Ord. No. 2016-02-02, § 2, 3-21-2016) State Law reference— Rights and duties of pedestrians, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-90; pedestrians soliciting rides or business, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-97. Sec. 103-3. - Parades and demonstrations. (a) Definitions. As used in this section: Assemble shall be construed to mean any group of persons who assemble or congregate on any public street, alley, sidewalk or public park in the city for the purpose of displaying, advertising, promoting, exhibiting, advocating, or otherwise attracting public attention to or for any cause or thing. Parade shall be construed to mean any group of persons marching or promenading on and along any public street, alley, sidewalk or public park in the city for the purpose of displaying, advertising, promoting, exhibiting, advocating, or otherwise attracting public attention to or for any cause or thing. (b) Permit required; unlawful participation. It shall be unlawful for persons to parade or assemble or congregate on any public street, alley, sidewalk or public park in the city for the purposes as defined in this section unless the city council shall have previously approved and authorized such parade or assembly. Any person participating in or attending any parade or assembly which has not been authorized and approved by the city council shall be considered as a part of the group constituting such parade or assembly, and upon conviction thereof shall be punished as provided in section 1-6. (c) Application for permit. Any persons desiring to parade or assemble on any of the public streets, alleys, sidewalks or public parks of the city for any of the purposes defined in this section shall file an application, at least 15 days before the date set for such parade or assembly, with the city manager setting forth the time, place and purpose of such parade or assembly, and when such application is approved by the city council, such parade or assembly will be authorized. (d) The city council shall issue a parade or assembly permit when, from a consideration of the application and from such other information as may otherwise be obtained, the council finds that: (1) The conduct of the parade or assembly will not substantially interrupt the safe and orderly movement of other traffic contiguous to its route; (2) The conduct of the parade or assembly will not require the diversion of so great a number of police officers of the city to properly police the line of movement and the areas contiguous thereto as to prevent normal police protection to the city; (3) The conduct of such parade or assembly will not require the diversion of so great a number of ambulances as to prevent normal ambulance service to portions of the city other than that to be occupied by the proposed line of march and areas contiguous thereto; (4) The concentration of persons, animals and vehicles at assembly points of the parade or assembly will not unduly interfere with proper fire and police protection of, or ambulance service to, areas contiguous to such assembly areas; (5) The conduct of such parade or assembly will not interfere with the movement of firefighting equipment en route to a fire; (6) The conduct of the parade or assembly is not reasonably likely to cause injury to persons or property, provoke disorderly conduct or create a disturbance; (7) The parade or assembly is scheduled to move from its point of origin to its point of termination expeditiously and without unreasonable delays en route; (8) The parade or assembly is not to be held for the sole purpose of advertising any product, goods or event, and is not designed to be held purely for private profit. (Ord. No. 2016-02-02, § 2, 3-21-2016) State Law reference— Operation of motor vehicles in parades, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-7; power of local authorities to regulate or prohibit processions or assemblages on the highways, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(3). Sec. 103-4. - Driving on sidewalks. The operator of a vehicle or bicycle shall not drive or ride within any sidewalk area, including sidewalks in shopping centers, except at a permanent or temporary driveway. (Ord. No. 2016-02-02, § 2, 3-21-2016) State Law reference— Parking on sidewalk, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-203. Sec. 103-5. - Truck routes. (a) It shall be unlawful for loaded trucks and empty trucks or any other vehicle heavier than five tons to travel on or use the streets of the city other than those streets which are marked "truck route". Nothing in this section shall prevent trucks from entering other streets and the business section of the city for the purpose of collecting solid waste, loading or unloading freight, packages or merchandise. This section shall not apply to city fire and rescue vehicles and city service vehicles. (b) Any motor vehicle weighing more than five tons, when loaded or empty, making a scheduled or definite stop within the city for the purpose of loading or unloading shall proceed over or upon designated truck routes set out in this section to the nearest point of its scheduled or definite stop and shall proceed thereto, load or unload and return, by the most direct route to its point of departure from said designated truck route. (c) The owner, or any other person, employing or otherwise directing the driver of any vehicle shall not require or knowingly permit the operation of such vehicle upon a street in a manner contrary to this section. (Ord. No. 2016-02-02, § 2, 3-21-2016) State Law reference— Power of local authorities to regulate the use of heavily traveled streets, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(13). Sec. 103-6. - Load limits on residential streets. (a) When signs are erected giving notice thereof, it shall be unlawful for any person to operate a vehicle with a gross weight in excess of the amounts specified on such signs at any time upon any of the streets or parts of streets for which said signs are erected. (b) The council may, upon application and good cause being shown, issue a special permit in writing authorizing the applicant to operate or move a vehicle or combination of vehicles of a size or weight exceeding the maximum gross weight specified by posted signs over those streets named in the permit which are under the jurisdiction of the city. (Ord. No. 2016-02-02, § 2, 3-21-2016) Sec. 103-7. - Obstructing traffic at schools. It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle on the street in front of any school where signs are erected or markings placed indicating no parking. (Ord. No. 2016-02-02, § 2, 3-21-2016) Sec. 103-8. - Operating vehicle to avoid traffic control device. It shall be unlawful for any person to cause any vehicle to travel over or through any private property in an attempt to avoid or fail to comply with any traffic control devices or any lawful order or direction of any law enforcement officer with authority to direct, control or regulate traffic within the limits of the city. (Ord. No. 2016-02-02, § 2, 3-21-2016) State Law reference— Traffic signs, signals and markings, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-20 et seq. Sec. 103-9. - Operation of recreational vehicles on public streets. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a recreational vehicle upon the public streets, paved recreational paths, sidewalks, and other areas accessible by the public located within the city unless the recreational vehicle is both designed for use on public roads and subject to motor vehicle registration. "Recreational vehicles" shall be defined as any pleasure cart which is powered by electricity, battery, or gasoline/petroleum product and specifically includes those vehicles commonly referred to as go-carts, four-wheeler vehicles, ATV's, mini-bikes, dune buggies or any other land motor vehicle designed for recreational use off public roads unless such vehicle has been licensed for use on public roadways by a competent licensing authority. Golf carts are excluded from the definition of recreational vehicles contained in this section. (Ord. No. 2016-02-02, § 2, 3-21-2016) Secs. 103-10—103-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - SPEED[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Speed restrictions, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-180 et seq.
Sec. 103-31. - Maximum limit generally. The maximum speed limit at all points within the city, unless otherwise provided, shall be 30 miles per hour. This maximum limit shall not be construed to permit the operation of vehicles at such rate if common prudence upon the part of the operator would require a lower rate of speed under existing circumstances. (Ord. No. 2016-02-02, § 2, 3-21-2016) State Law reference— Maximum speed limits, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-181. Sec. 103-32. - Maximum limits on particular streets authorized. The council may from time to time establish speed limits on particular streets or parts of streets greater or less than 30 miles per hour. When signs are in place showing such designation, it shall be unlawful to operate a vehicle in excess of the speed so posted. Such streets and portions of streets and the speeds thereon are as shown in enactments of council on file in the city manager's office. (Ord. No. 2016-02-02, § 2, 3-21-2016) State Law reference— Alteration of speed limits by local authorities, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-183. Secs. 103-33—103-55. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - PARKING[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— Stopping, standing and parking, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-200 et seq.; authority to regulate or prohibit stopping, standing, or parking, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(1).
Sec. 103-56. - Definitions. For the purpose of this article, the following words shall have the definitions as provided: (a) Controlled parking space shall mean any parking space that is designated for a specified purpose and to be used by certain vehicles only, such as, but not limited to, bus zones, loading zones, official vehicle parking spaces and handicapped parking spaces. (b) Improper parking charge shall mean the monetary charge assessed against the owner or operator of a vehicle that is occupying a parking space beyond the maximum legally established time for that parking space or which is parked contrary to the provisions of this article. (c) Notice shall mean the notice or ticket issued by an officer of the city informing the owner or operator of a vehicle that such vehicle is parked contrary to the provisions of this article. (d) Officer shall mean either an authorized civilian employee of the city police department or an authorized police officer of the city police department. (e) Official vehicles shall mean any authorized vehicle operated by the city for official purposes, including but not limited to vehicles operated by the city police department, fire department, and public works department. (f) Operator shall mean and include every individual who operates a vehicle as the owner thereof, or as the agent, employee or licensee of the owner, who is in actual control of a vehicle. (g) Owner shall mean the registered owner of a vehicle, according to the records maintained by the state department of motor vehicles. (h) Park or parking shall mean the standing or stopping of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, upon a street, except temporarily for the purpose of, and while actually engaged in, receiving or discharging passengers; loading or unloading goods or merchandise; or in the obedience to traffic regulations, signs or signals. (i) Parking space shall mean any area or space on a street or public place where a vehicle legally may park. (j) Person shall mean and include any individual, firm, partnership, corporation, or other association. (k) Public place shall mean any real property owned or leased by the city, including but not limited to public parking areas. (l) State department of motor vehicles shall mean any state governmental agency responsible for the issuance of certificates of title and/or certificates of registration for vehicles. (m) Street shall mean the entire width between the boundary lines of any public highway, street, road, right-of-way, alley, or way, located in the city and maintained by the state or city or subdivisions thereof. (Ord. No. 2016-02-02, § 2, 3-21-2016) Sec. 103-57. - Regulations. (a) No person shall park a vehicle or permit it to stand whether attended or unattended upon the following streets for more than two consecutive hours. (1) Liberty Street between 8 th Street and 6 th Street. (2) 6 th Street from Shadrack Street to Commerce Street. (3) Myrick Street adjacent to the Burke County Courthouse grounds. (b) No vehicle used in the transportation of flammable or explosive materials or substances shall be parked within the limits of any street, or other public place, except supervised public parking lots, between the hours from sunset to sunrise, provided, however, that this restriction shall not apply to the incidental stopping or parking of such vehicle in the carrying out of loading or unloading operations or in the performance of errands incidental to the business use of such vehicles if such vehicle is lighted with at least two white headlights and two red rear lights so constructed and so placed as to be observed under ordinary atmospheric conditions at a distance of not less than 500 feet. (c) No truck, trailer, semi-trailer, tractor, or other such type of vehicle shall be parked within the limits of any street, right-of-way or other public place, except public parking lots, for a period of greater than two hours between 12:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m. and then only if such vehicle is lighted with two white headlights and two red rear lights so constructed and so placed as to be observed under ordinary atmospheric conditions at a distance of not less than 300 feet. (d) No automobile, truck or other vehicle shall be parked within the limits of any street or other public place for the purpose of repairing, remodeling or otherwise working upon said vehicle. (e) No automobile, truck or other vehicle shall be parked or allowed to stand on the portion of street or highway between the curb or gutter and the sidewalk nor on any sidewalk except temporarily and during the process of loading or unloading. (f) No automobile, truck or other vehicle shall be parked or allowed to stand within the limits of any street and in a perpendicular position to the curb except temporarily for loading or unloading. (g) No automobile, truck or other vehicle other than fire trucks, ambulances or vehicles of law enforcement agencies during the performance of their respective duties, shall be parked or permitted to stand within 15 feet of any fire hydrant nor nearer than ten feet from the nearest street line of any intersecting street, nor in front of any crosswalks or driveways, nor in any passenger bus loading zones. (h) No automobiles, trucks or other vehicles shall be parked or permitted to stand within the boundaries of any street and within 500 feet of any building on fire. (i) No automobiles, trucks or other vehicles shall be parked further than two feet from the curb line if there is one, and if there is no curb, they shall not be parked within the main traveled portion of the street or highway. (j) No automobile, truck or other vehicle shall be parked or permitted to stand unless the brakes thereon are in good working order and properly set, nor shall such vehicle be parked or permitted to stand with its motor running, unless a competent operator is in charge and at the controls thereof. (k) When signs have been erected by any competent authority designating a "no parking" zone, the parking by any automobile, truck or other vehicle contrary thereto shall be a violation of this article. (Ord. No. 2016-02-02, § 2, 3-21-2016) Sec. 103-58. - No stopping or parking of vehicles except as permitted by this article. No person shall stop or park a vehicle on any street or public place except in accordance with the requirements of this article. (Ord. No. 2016-02-02, § 2, 3-21-2016) Sec. 103-59. - Restrictions on parking. (a) No person shall park a vehicle: (1) Within ten feet of any street intersection; (2) Within five feet of a private driveway, except where the surface of the street has been marked or designated by painted lines; (3) Within ten feet of a private driveway on a one-way street; (4) Where prohibited by an official traffic sign; (5) On any sidewalk; and (6) Where prohibited by markings painted on the surface of the street. (b) Vehicles shall be parked within any painted lines marking or designating a parking space. No vehicle shall stop or park in a manner such that the vehicle is straddling a painted line marking or designating a parking space or the vehicle is not within a parking space designated by such painted lines. (c) No person shall stop or park a vehicle upon any street or other public place if that vehicle is displayed as being for sale or is being used for the primary purpose of displaying advertising. (d) Vehicles parked within angular parking spaces shall have the front of the vehicle facing the curb of the street. (e) No person shall park a vehicle on any street so designated in section 103-57(a) for a period in excess of two hours. The city council may, after providing notice to the general public, by resolution, establish or modify the maximum parking time on any street. Section 103-57(a) shall then be amended to include the maximum parking limit on the street or streets identified in the resolution. (f) The city may, after providing notice to the general public, by resolution, establish or modify the location of any controlled parking space. (g) No person shall stop or park any vehicle in any area designated as a loading zone, except temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading and unloading of passengers or merchandise. (h) No person shall stop or park any vehicle in any area designated as an official vehicle parking space, unless the vehicle is an official vehicle. (i) No person shall park a vehicle in, allow the parking of a vehicle in, obstruct or allow the obstruction of a designated fire lane. Each day or part of a day during which the unlawful act or violation occurs shall constitute a separate offense. (j) No person shall stop or park a vehicle in any area designated as "handicap parking," except vehicles that have either a special license plate, decal, tag or card, issued by the state department of motor vehicles indicating the vehicle is for the use of a handicapped person. (Ord. No. 2016-02-02, § 2, 3-21-2016) Sec. 103-60. - Charges, penalties, and enforcement. (a) No person shall permit or cause a vehicle registered in his/her name to park contrary to any provision of this article. If the identity of the operator of a vehicle used or parked contrary to this article cannot be determined, the name of the person listed as the owner of the vehicle with the state department of motor vehicles shall be prima facie evidence that the registered owner was the operator of the vehicle. (b) Whenever an officer observes an unattended vehicle that is parked contrary to any provision of this article, he shall attach to the vehicle a notice informing the operator or owner that the vehicle has been parked contrary to the provisions of this article. The notice shall include the following information: (1) The location where the vehicle is parked; (2) The state registration or license number of the vehicle; (3) The date and time that the officer observed the vehicle parked or operated contrary to the provisions of this article; (4) A statement that if the owner or operator of the vehicle does not submit payment of an improper parking charge within 14 days after the notice is placed on the vehicle, the owner of the vehicle may be served with a summons to appear in municipal court to answer to charges of violating this article; (5) A statement that if the owner or operator wishes to challenge or contest the charges of violating this article before the municipal court, he may do so; and (6) Any other facts which the officer may determine necessary for a thorough understanding of the circumstances. (c) Officers shall have the authority to issue notices to any vehicle parked contrary to the provisions of this article or to issue a citation to any owner or operator of any vehicle parked contrary to the provisions of this article. Officers shall have the authority to issue notices by using either: (1) a pre-printed notice form to be filled in manually by the officer; or (2) an electronic device that produces a single paper copy of the notice to be issued. An electronic record or memory of the notice issued by an officer using an electronic device shall be maintained. Any paper printout of that electronic record or memory of the notice shall be prima facie evidence that it is a valid copy of the original notice issued. (d) The operator or owner of a vehicle receiving a notice that the vehicle was observed by an officer to be parked contrary to the provisions of this article shall submit full payment of the appropriate improper parking charge within 14 days of the time the notice was attached to the vehicle by placing the required sum of money in the envelope attached to the notice and: (1) delivering the notice envelope and payment to the city police department; or (2) mailing the notice envelope and payment to the City of Waynesboro at 628 Myrick Street, Waynesboro, Georgia 30830. The amount of the improper parking charge shall be as follows: (1) The improper parking charge shall be $20.00 regularly or $30.00 if issued in an area designated by the city council as an "enhanced penalty" area; (2) For violation of section 103-59(i) of this article, the improper parking charge shall be $250.00. (e) The failure, neglect, or refusal of an owner or operator to submit full payment of an improper parking charge within 14 days of the time the notice was attached to the vehicle owned or operated by him shall be unlawful and constitute a violation of this article. (f) The chief of police shall have the authority, at any time after the expiration of the 14 day period from the attachment of the notice to the vehicle or the issuance of a towing notice, but before a court summons has been issued, to send or cause to be sent notice(s) informing the owner of the vehicle that late penalty fees shall be assessed against him, unless the owner has submitted a written request to the municipal court asking that a hearing be scheduled regarding the violation of this article. (g) The amount of the initial late penalty fee for each violation shall be equal to the improper parking charge for such violation. The amount of the late penalty fee shall include any towing charge that was initially assessed. (h) If an owner or operator fails, neglects, or refuses to make full payment of the improper parking charge or towing charge, within 14 days of the time the notice was attached to the vehicle or the date that the towing notice was issued, then the chief of police, or an officer, may issue a summons to the operator or owner of the vehicle used in violation of this article to appear in court to answer to charges of violating this article. (i) Any person found by a court of law to be guilty of a violation of this article shall be required to pay: (1) For failure to pay the improper parking charge assessed, the minimum fine shall be $50.00 and the maximum fine shall not be more than $500.00; (2) For failure to pay the improper parking charge assessed under of section 103-59(i) of this article, the minimum fine shall be $510.00 and the maximum fine shall not be more than $1,000.00; (3) For failure to pay a towing charge assessed, the minimum fine shall be $110.00 and the maximum fine shall not be more than $500.00. (Ord. No. 2016-02-02, § 2, 3-21-2016) Sec. 103-61. - Removal of vehicles. (a) In the event that the chief of police or his designee determines that it is necessary to cause the removal, towage and storage of a vehicle parked contrary to the provisions of this article, the owner shall be required to pay a towing charge. (b) Whenever a vehicle is towed and stored the officer causing the vehicle to be towed and stored shall cause a towing notice to be sent to the owner by placing such towing notice in the mail within 24 hours of the time the vehicle was towed or removed. The towing notice shall include the following information: (1) The state registration or license number of the vehicle; (2) The location where the vehicle was parked; (3) The date and approximate time that the officer caused the vehicle to be removed or towed; (4) A statement that if the owner or operator of the vehicle does not submit payment of a towing charge within 14 days from the date of the notice, the owner of the vehicle may be served with a summons to appear in court to answer to charges of violating this article; (5) A statement that if the owner or operator wishes to challenge or contest the towing charge, the owner may submit a written request for a hearing before the municipal court within seven days of the issuance date of the towing notice. The written request shall be mailed or delivered to the Waynesboro Police Department at 628 Myrick Street, Waynesboro, Georgia 30830; (6) The issuance date of the towing notice; (7) A brief statement of the reason for the removal or towage of the vehicle; (8) The location of where the vehicle is being stored; and (9) Any other facts which the chief of police or his designee may determine necessary for a thorough understanding of the circumstances. (c) In the case of vehicles towed, the amount of the towing charge shall be $100.00. (d) The operator or owner of a vehicle receiving a towing notice shall submit full payment of the towing charge within 14 days of the date the towing notice was issued by: (1) delivering payment to the city police department; or (2) mailing such payment to the city police department at 628 Myrick Street Waynesboro, Georgia 30830. (e) The failure, neglect, or refusal of an owner or operator to submit full payment of a towing charge within 14 days of the date the notice was issued shall be unlawful and constitute a violation of this article. (f) In the event that a decision is made by the municipal court judge to vacate the assessment of a towing charge, any sums paid by the owner or operator in satisfaction of the towing charge shall be refunded within ten days of the decision. (Ord. No. 2016-02-02, § 2, 3-21-2016) Sec. 103-62. - Multiple unpaid parking violations. (a) At any time subsequent to the accumulation of ten unpaid parking violations or the accumulation of unpaid parking fines in excess of $90.00 attributable to motor vehicle(s) registered to an individual, the chief of police or his designee may send a notice by certified mail to the registered owner of said vehicle(s). Said notice may also be given by affixing same to the driver's side window of any vehicle known to be registered to an individual that meets the criteria as detailed in this paragraph. This notice shall contain the following information: (1) The date, time, and location of the violations leading to the issuance of the notice; (2) A statement to the clear effect that failure to resolve the violations prior to a certain specified date not less than five days subsequent to the date of the notice, will lead to the towing of any vehicle registered in the name of the individual pending such resolution; (3) A statement that the recipient of the notice may contact the chief of police or his appropriate designee in writing within three days of the owner's receipt of the notice or the date the notice was affixed to owner's vehicle to request a hearing on the subject of the violations. (b) Upon receipt of a properly submitted request from an owner pursuant to this section, the chief of police or his designee shall arrange a hearing before the municipal court. (Ord. No. 2016-02-02, § 2, 3-21-2016) Secs. 103-63—103-70. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT DIVISION 1. - IMPOUNDING VEHICLES
Sec. 103-71. - Authorized. (a) Whenever a police officer or other officer acting under authority or direction of the city shall find any vehicle parked on any street or other place in violation of law or in violation of the ordinances of the city, or abandoned for at least five days on any street or other public place, and such officer is unable to find the owner, operator, or other person responsible for such vehicle in the immediate vicinity after making a reasonable search and investigation, it shall be his duty to take possession of such vehicle and tow it to a place of storage and keep it in possession of the city until claimed by the person entitled to its possession, if claimed within the time fixed in this article; provided, however, that the person claiming such vehicle shall pay all lawful costs as fixed in this article. If deemed necessary by such officer, he shall call upon a garage man or other person equipped for towing and storing such vehicles. (b) Whenever any officer shall find upon any street, or at any other place within the city, any vehicle broken-down, wrecked, disabled, stalled, or in any condition or situation as to render the vehicle likely to endanger life, limb or property, and the owner, operator or person in charge is unable or unwilling to take the proper steps to remove the danger or to make the necessary correction with reasonable promptness, such officer shall cause the vehicle to be removed, impounded and kept in the manner specified in subsection (a) of this section, to be released upon compliance with the requirements of section 103-72 as to payment of costs and expenses. (c) In all cases where the operator of a vehicle is found upon the public streets or public places of the city ill, injured, intoxicated, or for any reason in a condition rendering him unfit to operate the vehicle, the officers shall tow away and store such vehicle in the manner provided in this section, until released by compliance with the requirements of section 103-72. (Ord. No. 2016-02-02, § 2, 3-21-2016) State Law reference— When police officers may remove vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-206; abandoned motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-11-1 et seq. Sec. 103-72. - Redemption of impounded vehicles. The owner or person entitled to possession of a vehicle impounded pursuant to section 103-71 may redeem such vehicle at any time within 30 days of the date of impoundment by paying to the city the actual costs of impounding, towing and storing such vehicle plus any penalty that may be assessed for violation of this article or any ordinance. (Ord. No. 2016-02-02, § 2, 3-21-2016) State Law reference— Duty of person removing or storing motor vehicle, O.C.G.A. § 40-11-2. Sec. 103-73. - Sale of unredeemed vehicles. If the owner or person entitled to possession of a vehicle impounded under section 103-71 fails to redeem such vehicle as provided in section 103-72, the chief of police may proceed to effectuate its disposition by selling it after advertising such sale in the local legal organ one time and posting notice of such sale in the lobby of City Hall. Such sale shall be to the highest sealed bidder for cash, bids to be opened not less than ten days after publication and posting of notice. (Ord. No. 2016-02-02, § 2, 3-21-2016) Secs. 103-74—103-95. - Reserved.

div.head: Chapter 106 - SUBDIVISIONS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Entry of approval of subdivision plat prior to recording, O.C.G.A. § 15-6-67(d); procedures for approval of subdivision plats, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-150 et seq.; subdivision of areas proposed to be incorporated, O.C.G.A. § 36-31-4; Georgia Land Sales Act, O.C.G.A. § 44-3-1 et seq.

div.head: Chapter 110 - TAXATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Local taxation of insurance companies, O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.1 et seq.; revenue and taxation, O.C.G.A. § 48-1-1 et seq.; municipal taxation, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-350 et seq.; local taxation of rooms, lodgings or accommodations, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 110-1—110-26. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - PROPERTY TAXES[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Ad valorem taxation of property, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-1 et seq.; municipal taxation, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-350 et seq.
Sec. 110-27. - Returns; required, date, assessment. All taxable property shall be returned for taxes to the city manager on or before April 1 in each year, and the return shall include all property held, owned or controlled in the city on January 1 in the year in which the return is made; provided, however, that no return is required of a taxpayer whose property is the same as that taxed in the preceding year by the city. All property, whether returned or not, shall be assessed by the Burke County Board of Assessors from the best information obtainable. (Code 1974, § 8-21; Code 1995, § 98-27) State Law reference— Time for making tax returns, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-18; municipal board of tax assessors, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-353. Sec. 110-28. - Fixing tax rate. (a) Date. At such time the tax digest is made available by the county, or as soon thereafter as practicable, in each year, the city council shall prescribe and fix the rate of taxation for the current year. (b) Meeting; report; submitting digest. It shall be the duty of the city manager to make a report to a meeting of the city council called for the purpose of fixing the rate of taxation for the current year. The tax digest shall show the gross amount and value of property entered therein for taxation for the current year. At such meeting, the city council shall proceed to fix and declare the rate of taxation as provided in this article. (Code 1974, §§ 8-22, 8-23; Code 1995, § 98-28) Sec. 110-29. - Due and delinquent dates. All taxes levied as provided in this article shall be considered due on receipt of the bill and delinquent after 60 days from the date of receipt of the tax bill. (Code 1974, § 8-24; Code 1995, § 98-29) Sec. 110-30. - Tax executions; issuing, enforcement. Should any person owing taxes to the city fail or refuse to pay such taxes when required to do so, the city manager shall issue execution for such taxes, after the expiration of ten days from such refusal, which execution shall be directed to the chief of police of the city, and all and singular the sheriffs, deputy sheriffs and constables of the state, which execution shall be enforced by levy and sale under the same rules governing sheriffs' sales. (Code 1974, § 8-30; Code 1995, § 98-30) State Law reference— Tax executions, O.C.G.A. § 48-3-1 et seq. Secs. 110-31—110-44. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - HOTEL/MOTEL TAX[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— Local taxation of rooms, lodgings or accommodations, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50 et seq.
Sec. 110-45. - Excise tax levied. Pursuant to the provisions of an act of the general assembly authorizing each municipality in the State of Georgia to impose, levy and collect an excise tax upon the furnishing for value to the public of any room or rooms, lodgings or accommodations furnished by any person or legal entity licensed by or required to pay business or occupation taxes to the municipality for operating a hotel, motel, inn, lodge, tourist camp, cabin or any other place in which rooms, lodgings or accommodations are regularly furnished for value, provided no such tax shall be levied upon the sale or charges for any rooms, lodgings or accommodations furnished for periods of more than 30 consecutive days, or for the use of meeting rooms, there is hereby levied an excise tax in the amount of five percent of the charges to the public for such furnishing of any room or rooms, lodgings or accommodation within the city. (Ord. No. 2006-03-01, § 1, 4-24-2006; Ord. No. 2017-08-01, § 2, 8-21-2017) State Law reference— Room tax authorized, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51 et seq. Sec. 110-46. - Forms to city manager. Each person, firm, or corporation collecting said tax shall on or before the 20th day of each month transmit to the city manager or a designated representative upon forms as prescribed by the city returns showing the total charges for the furnishing of such rooms, lodging or accommodations as provided for herein during the preceding calendar month and shall account for and remit the tax levied herein. (Ord. No. 2006-03-01, § 2, 4-24-2006) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-53.2. Sec. 110-47. - Allowable taxes. Each person, firm or corporation collecting said tax as provided for herein shall be allowed three percent of the tax due and accounted for and remitted to the city in the form of a deduction in submitting the report and paying the amount due provided said amount due is not delinquent at the time of payment. (Ord. No. 2006-03-01, § 3, 4-24-2006) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-52. Sec. 110-48. - Penalties. (a) When any person, firm or corporation liable hereunder shall fail to make any return or pay the full amount of the tax required herein, there shall be imposed a specific penalty to be added to the tax in the amount of five percent or $5.00, whichever is greater, for each additional 30 days, or fraction thereof, during which the failure continues, not to exceed 25 percent or $25.00 in the aggregate, whichever is greater; provided, however, if such failure is due to providential cause shown to the satisfaction of the city manager in affidavit form attached to the return and remittance within ten days of due date, such returns may be accepted exclusive of penalties and interest. In the case of a false or fraudulent return or the failure to file a return, where willful intent exists to defraud the city of any tax due herein, a specific penalty of 50 percent of the tax due shall be assessed. (b) When any person, firm or corporation fails to remit the tax, or any portion thereof, on or before the day when such tax shall be required by law to be paid, there shall be added to the amount due interest at the rate provided for executions from the date until paid. (c) All penalties and interest imposed herein shall be payable and collectible by the city in the manner as if they were a part of the tax imposed. (Ord. No. 2006-03-01, § 4, 4-24-2006) Sec. 110-49. - Revenues budgeted and applied for promotion of city. All revenues raised pursuant to said tax shall be budgeted and applied for the promotion of the City of Waynesboro in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(a)(3)(A). (Ord. No. 2006-03-01, § 5, 4-24-2006)

div.head: Chapter 112 - UNRULY GATHERINGS
div.p: Sec. 112-1. - Unruly gatherings; public nuisance. (a) It shall be a public nuisance to conduct a gathering of 15 or more persons on any private property in a manner which constitutes a substantial disturbance of the quiet enjoyment of private or public property in a significant segment of a neighborhood, as a result of conduct constituting a violation of law. Illustrative of such unlawful conduct is excessive noise or traffic, obstruction of public streets by crowds or vehicles, illegal parking, public drunkenness, public urination, public indecency, the service of alcohol to minors, fights, disturbances of the peace, and litter. (b) A gathering constituting a public nuisance may be abated by all reasonable means including, but not limited to, an order requiring the gathering to be disbanded and citation and/or arrest of any law violators under any applicable city ordinances and state statutes. (Ord. No. 2016-10-01, § 3, 11-28-2016) Sec. 112-2. - Notice of unruly gathering; posting. (a) When the police department intervenes at a gathering which constitutes a nuisance under this chapter, the premises at which such nuisance occurred shall be posted with a notice stating that the intervention of the police has been necessitated as a result of a public nuisance under this chapter caused by an event at the premises, the date of the police intervention, and that any subsequent event within the period set forth below on the same premises, which necessitates police intervention, shall result in the joint and several liability of any guests causing the public nuisance, or any persons who own or are residents of the property at which the public nuisance occurred, or who sponsored the event constituting the public nuisance as more fully set forth below. Any notice posted shall remain posted for a rolling calendar year from the date the police department intervenes. For example, a notice posted on July 30 shall remain posted until July 29 of the following year. (b) The notice posted under this section shall be no less than eight inches x 14 inches in size and shall be neon green in color. The notice shall be constructed of a durable, weather resistant, adhesive material. The notice shall be affixed to the dwelling or structure and shall be posted in a conspicuous place. The police chief or his designee shall determine the location in which such notice is posted in order to achieve both the security of the notice and its prominent display. (c) The residents and owner of such property shall be jointly responsible for ensuring that such notice is not removed or defaced and it shall be a code violation carrying a penalty of a minimum, mandatory $100.00 fine in addition to any other penalties which may be due under this chapter if such notice is removed, obscured or defaced. (Ord. No. 2016-10-01, § 3, 11-28-2016) Sec. 112-3. - Mailing of notice to property owner. Notice of the intervention shall also be mailed via certified and regular U.S. mail to any property owner listed on the Burke County Tax Assessors' records. The notice shall advise the property owner that any subsequent such intervention within posting periods set forth in subsection 112-2(a) on the same premises shall result in liability of the property owner for all penalties associated with such intervention as more particularly set forth below. (Ord. No. 2016-10-01, § 3, 11-28-2016) Sec. 112-4. - Persons liable for subsequent response to gathering constituting a public nuisance. (a) If the police department is required to respond to a gathering constituting a public nuisance on the premises during any posting periods set forth in subsection 112-2(a), the following persons shall be jointly and severally liable for fines as set forth below: (1) The person or persons who own the property where the gathering constituting the public nuisance took place, provided that notice has been mailed to the owner of the property as set forth herein and the gathering occurs at least 14 days after the mailing of such notice. (2) The person or persons residing on or otherwise in control of the property where such gathering took place. (3) The person or persons who organized or sponsored such gathering. (4) All persons attending such gatherings who engage in any activity resulting in the public nuisance. (5) Nothing in this section shall be construed to impose liability on the resident or owners of the premises or sponsor of the gathering, for the conduct of persons who are present without the express or implied consent of the resident or sponsor, as long as the resident and sponsor have taken all steps reasonably necessary to exclude such uninvited participants from the premises, including landlords who are actively attempting to evict a tenant from the premises. (b) Where an invited guest engages in conduct which the sponsor or resident could not reasonably foresee and the conduct is an isolated instance of a guest at the event violating the law which the sponsor is unable to reasonably control without the intervention of the police, the unlawful conduct of the individual guest shall not be attributable to the sponsor or resident for the purposes of determining whether the event constitutes a public nuisance under this section. (Ord. No. 2016-10-01, § 3, 11-28-2016) Sec. 112-5. - Penalties for violation. (a) It shall be a code violation punishable as set forth herein when intervention at the same location to abate a gathering constituting a public nuisance occurs within any posting periods set forth in subsection 112-2(a) after the property was posted: (1) For the first intervention in a posting period the fine shall be a minimum mandatory $300.00; (2) For the second such intervention in a posting period the fine shall be a minimum mandatory $400.00; (3) For any further such responses in a posting period the fine shall be a minimum mandatory $500.00. (b) In addition to the above, the municipal court shall be authorized to order the person or persons in violation to perform community service. For a first intervention ordering community service shall be discretionary. For a second or third intervention, the municipal court shall, in addition to the monetary penalty set forth above, order the person or persons in violation to perform not less than 25 hours of community service for a second intervention and not less than 50 hours of community service for a third intervention. (Ord. No. 2016-10-01, § 3, 11-28-2016) Secs. 112-6—112-19. - Reserved.

div.head: Chapter 114 - UTILITIES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Dumping wastes into sewer pipeline, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-2; damaging or interfering with utility property, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-25; Georgia Utility Facility Protection Act, O.C.G.A. § 25-9-1 et seq.; franchises, contracts with public utilities, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-2(7); municipal water and sewage systems, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-5; disposal of public utility plants or properties, O.C.G.A. § 36-37-7 et seq.; contracts to provide industrial wastewater treatment services, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-2; public utilities, O.C.G.A. § 46-1-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 114-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Each customer, in sections applicable to multiple units, means each meter, rather than the number of units so connected. (Code 1974, § 22-41; Code 1995, § 106-1) State Law reference— Damaging, injuring or interfering with property of public utility companies, municipalities or political subdivisions, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-25. Sec. 114-2. - Emergency gas procedure plan. There is instituted the emergency gas procedure plan, whereby this city will go to the aid of another city in this vicinity, under reciprocal agreement, in the case of necessity. This shall cover the lending of materials and supplies in the time of emergency, the recipient city to reimburse for such materials and supplies furnished or labor needed. (Code 1974, § 22-2; Code 1995, § 106-3) Sec. 114-3. - Use of utilities without authority. It shall be unlawful for any person to use any city utility service unless he is a duly registered customer of such utility. (Code 1974, § 22-3; Code 1995, § 106-4) State Law reference— Theft of services, O.C.G.A. § 16-8-5. Sec. 114-4. - Septic tanks may be authorized in low areas. The building inspector and county health department shall have the right to give permission to homeowners and contractors to install septic tanks in low areas where there may be sewage problems. (Code 1974, § 22-21; Code 1995, § 106-5) Secs. 114-5—114-15. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - OUTDOOR WATERING RESTRICTIONS
Sec. 114-16. - Definitions. When used in this article: Address means the "house number" (a numeric or alphanumeric designation) that, together with the street name, describes a physical location of a specific property. The term "even numbered address" means a house number ending with the number 0, 2, 4, 6, 8, or no house number. The term "odd numbered address" means a house number ending with the number 1, 3, 5, 7, or 9. Declared drought response level means one of four levels of drought that can be declared based on the severity of drought conditions, with one being the least severe and four being the most severe. Sec. 114-17. - Applicability of article. The rules provided for in this article apply to any entity, and its customers, permitted by the Georgia Environmental Protection Division (EPD) for water withdrawal or for operation of a drinking water system. Sec. 114-18. - Outdoor water use schedule during non-drought periods. (a) Outdoor water use other than exempted activities shall occur only as follows: (1) Odd-numbered addresses: Outdoor water use is allowed on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Sundays. (2) Even-numbered addresses: Outdoor water use is allowed on Mondays, Wednesdays and Saturdays. (b) During non-drought periods, outdoor water use, may occur on scheduled days within the hours of 12:00 midnight to 10:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. to 12:00 midnight. Sec. 114-19. - Outdoor water use schedule during declared drought response levels. (a) The director of the environmental protection division is authorized to make drought declarations. (b) During declared drought conditions, outdoor water use other than activities exempted in section 114-20, shall occur only during scheduled hours on the scheduled days. (c) Declared drought response level one. Outdoor water use may occur on scheduled days within the hours of 12:00 midnight to 10:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. to 12:00 midnight. (1) Scheduled days for odd-numbered addresses are Tuesdays, Thursdays and Sundays. (2) Scheduled days for even-numbered addresses are Mondays, Wednesdays and Saturdays. (3) Use of hydrants for any purpose other than firefighting, public health, safety or flushing is prohibited. (d) Declared drought response level two. Outdoor water use may occur on scheduled days within the hours of 12:00 midnight to 10:00 a.m. (1) Scheduled days for odd-numbered addresses are Tuesdays, Thursdays and Sundays. (2) Scheduled days for even-numbered addresses and golf course fairways are Mondays, Wednesdays and Saturdays. (3) The following uses are prohibited: a. Using hydrants for any purpose other than firefighting, public health, safety or flushing. b. Washing hard surfaces, such as streets, gutters, sidewalks and driveways, except when necessary for public health and safety. (e) Declared drought response level three. Outdoor water use may occur on the scheduled day within the hours of 12:00 midnight to 10:00 a.m. (1) The scheduled day for odd-numbered addresses is Sunday. (2) The scheduled day for even-numbered addresses and golf course fairways is Saturday. (3) The following uses are prohibited: a. Using hydrants for any purpose other than firefighting, public health, safety or flushing. b. Washing hard surfaces, such as streets, gutters, sidewalks, driveways, except when necessary for public health and safety. c. Filling installed swimming pools except when necessary for health care or structural integrity. d. Washing vehicles, such as cars, trucks, boats, trailers, motorbikes, airplanes, golf carts. e. Washing buildings or structures except for immediate fire protection. f. Noncommercial fundraisers, such as car washes. g. Using water for ornamental purposes, such as fountains, reflecting pools, and waterfalls except when necessary to support aquatic life. (f) Declared drought response level four - No outdoor water use is allowed, other than for activities exempted in section 5-5-5, or as the EPD director may order. Sec. 114-20. - Exemptions. (a) This article shall not apply to the following outdoor water uses: (1) Capture and re-use of cooling system condensate or stormwater in compliance with applicable local ordinances. (2) Re-use of gray water in compliance with applicable local ordinances. (3) Outdoor irrigation using water obtained exclusively from a private well. (b) The following established landscape water uses are exempt from the outdoor water use schedules of this article: (1) Use of reclaimed wastewater by a designated user from a system permitted by EPD to provide reclaimed wastewater. (2) Irrigation of personal food gardens. (3) Drip and soaker hose irrigation systems. (4) Hand watering with a hose that has an automatic cutoff nozzle, or with hand-held containers. (c) Newly (in place less than 30 days) installed landscapes are subject to the following: (1) Irrigation of newly installed landscapes is allowed any day of the week, but only during allowed hours for the drought response level in effect, for a period of 30 days following installation. No watering is allowed during drought response level four. (2) For new landscapes installed by certified or licensed professionals, commercial exemptions apply. (d) The following golf course outdoor water uses are exempt from the outdoor water use schedules of this article: (1) Use of reclaimed wastewater by a designated user from a system permitted by EPD to provide reclaimed wastewater. (2) Irrigation of fairways during times of non-drought and declared drought response level one. (3) Irrigation of tees during times of non-drought and declared drought response levels one, two and three. (4) Irrigation of greens. (e) The following commercial outdoor water uses are exempt from the outdoor water use schedules of this article: (1) Professionally certified or licensed landscapers, golf course contractors, and sports turf landscapers, during installation and 30 days following installation only. Professional landscapers must be certified or licensed for commercial exemptions to apply. (2) Irrigation contractors, during installation and as needed for proper maintenance and adjustments only. (3) Sod producers. (4) Ornamental growers. (5) Fruit and vegetable growers. (6) Retail garden centers. (7) Hydro-seeding. (8) Power-washing. (9) Construction sites. (10) Producers of food and fiber. (11) Car washes. (12) Other activities essential to daily business. (13) Watering-in of pesticides and herbicides on turf. Sec. 114-21. - Regional options. (a) Local and regional water providers are authorized to implement additional outdoor water use restrictions within their jurisdictions. (b) Local and regional water providers may request approval of alternative days for outdoor water use for purposes of enforcement, peak water usage, timing of recovery days, and other valid reasons. Approval shall be contingent upon: (1) Written notification to, and approval by, EPD of the alternate watering schedule; (2) Enactment of a local ordinance allowing no more than three days a week outdoor watering during times of day consistent with the level of drought as set forth in sections 114-118 and 114-119; and (3) Regional consistency. Secs. 114-22—114-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - TAPS AND CONNECTIONS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 114-31. - Sewer connections required when available. (a) Except as otherwise provided in this article, all houses on premises within 90 feet of the city sanitary sewer shall be connected thereto. (b) Where property may be served by a city sanitary sewer, every building shall be connected thereto. If there should be more than one building on the property, each building shall be connected separately to the sewer if the number of fixtures in all buildings exceeds ten. The term "fixtures" as used in this section, are any water appliances emptying water into the sewer. (Code 1974, § 22-20; Code 1995, § 106-31) Cross reference— Health and sanitation, ch. 58. Sec. 114-32. - Supervision of work. A tap or connection with the city sewer, water or gas line shall be made by the superintendent of the gas department, the street and public works department or the water department, as the case may be, or a city employee designated by him, who shall have authority to require the tap or connection to be made in accordance with the required regulations of the gas department, the street and public works department or the water department, as the case may be. Sec. 114-46. - Required. Before any tap or connection with a city sewer, water or gas line shall be made, it shall be necessary that the owner of the property to be served by such connection, shall first obtain from the city manager a permit therefor. No. 92-8-2, 9-8-1992) Secs. 114-49—114-70. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - SERVICE RATES AND CHARGES
Sec. 114-71. - Gas. (a) Rate schedule. Gas rates shall be established by resolution of the mayor and city council. (b) The city will make changes in the price of natural gas as the cost of gas fluctuates from the suppliers and when recommended by city engineers and the city gas consultant. (Code 1974, §§ 22-36, 22-37; Code 1995, § 106-71; Ord. No. 93-9-3, 11-1-1993; Ord. No. 96-02-1, 4-1-1996) Sec. 114-72. - Water and gas deposits. All metered water will be sold at rates established by resolution of the city council. (Code 1974, § 22-38; Code 1995, § 106-73; Ord. No. 89-2, 3-20-1989; Ord. No. 95-2-1, 3-20-1995; Ord. No. 2004-12-01, 1-20-2005) Sec. 114-74. - Billing; payment date; delinquency. (a) Each utility customer of the city shall receive a statement of his utility account each month. Customers' accounts are billed in accordance with the route in which the account is maintained. There are currently four routes established within the city. (b) Utility accounts are due upon receipt and are considered delinquent ten days thereafter. A penalty of ten percent will be added to delinquent bills. (c) Customer accounts that are 30 days past due will have service disconnected. (d) Once service is discontinued, it will not be reinstated until the account has been paid in full and a reconnection fee as established by resolution of mayor and city council is paid. All appeals from discontinuance of service must be in writing and presented to the administration department at city hall. (Code 1974, § 22-42; Code 1995, § 106-77; Ord. No. 1038, 12-17-1979; Ord. No. 89-3, 10-2-1989; Ord. No. 2017-05-02, § 2, 6-5-2017) Sec. 114-75. - Defective meters; testing; charge. All utility customers of the city who claim that their meter is not correctly registering shall deposit the sum of $50.00 with the city manager, after which the meter will be removed and checked by the city. Upon checking, if the variance, if any, does not exceed two percent, plus or minus, the meter will be reinstalled and the deposit advanced forfeited to the city. If, upon checking, the meter shows a variation in excess of two percent, plus or minus, the city shall refund the sum advanced and install a new meter. Sec. 114-151. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Damage means and includes the substantial weakening of structural or lateral support of an underground utility, penetration or destruction of any protective coating, housing or other protective device of an underground utility, and the partial or complete severance of an underground utility. Demolish or demolition means any operation by which a structure or mass of material is wrecked, razed, rendered, moved or removed by means of any tools, equipment, or discharge of explosives. Excavate or excavation means an operation for the purpose of the movement or removal of earth, rock or other materials in or on the ground by use of mechanized equipment or by discharge of explosives, and including augering, backfilling, digging, ditching, drilling, grading, plowing-in, pulling-in, ripping, scraping, trenching and tunneling, but not including the tilling of soil for agricultural purposes. Mechanized equipment means equipment operated by means of mechanical power, including trenchers, bulldozers, power shovels, augers, backhoes, scrapers, drills, cable and pipe plows and other equipment used for plowing-in or pulling-in cable or pipe. Operator means any person who owns or operates a utility. Person means any individual; any corporation, partnership, association, or any other entity organized under the laws of any state; any subdivision or instrumentality of a state; and any employee, agent or legal representative thereof. Utility means any line, system or facility used for producing, storing, conveying, transmitting, or distributing communication, electricity, gas, petroleum, petroleum products, hazardous liquids, water, steam or sewerage. Working day means every day except Saturdays, Sundays, and national and legal state holidays. (Code 1995, § 106-15; Ord. No. 1059, § 2, 9-6-1983) Sec. 114-152. - Compliance with article. A permit issued pursuant to law authorizing excavation or demolition operations, or any action taken as required by law, shall not be deemed to relieve a person from the responsibility for complying with the provisions of this article. (Code 1995, § 106-152; Ord. No. 1059, § 3, 9-6-1983) Sec. 114-153. - Prohibition. Except as provided in section 114-157, no person may excavate in a street, highway, public space, a private easement of an operator, or near the location of a utility installed on the premises of a customer served by such utility, or demolish a building, without having first ascertained in the manner prescribed in sections 114-155 and 114-156 the location of all underground utilities in the area that would be affected by the proposed excavation or demolition. (Code 1995, § 106-153; Ord. No. 1059, § 4, 9-6-1983) State Law reference— Powers of municipalities concerning facilities located on public road or street rights-of-way, O.C.G.A. § 25-9-11. Sec. 114-154. - Filing requirements of utility operators. (a) Each operator having underground utilities in this city shall file with the city manager a list containing the name of the operator and the name, title, address and telephone number of its representative designated to receive the written or telephonic notice of intent required by section 114-155. (b) Changes in any of the information contained in the list filed under subsection (a) of this section shall be filed by the operator with the city manager within five working days of such change. (Code 1995, § 106-154; Ord. No. 1059, § 5, 9-6-1983) Sec. 114-155. - Notice of intent to excavate or demolish. (a) Except as provided in section 114-157, before commencing any excavation or demolition operation designated in section 114-153, each person responsible for such excavation or demolition shall serve written or telephonic notice of intent to excavate or demolish at least three, but not more than ten, full working days on each operator which has filed a list required by section 114-154, indicating that it has underground utilities located in the proposed area of excavation or demolition. (b) The written or telephonic notice required by subsection (a) of this section must contain the name, address and telephone number of the person filing the notice of intent and, if different, the person responsible for the excavation or demolition, the starting date, anticipated duration and type of excavation or demolition operation to be conducted, the location of the proposed excavation or demolition, and whether or not explosives are to be used. (c) If the notification required by this section is made by telephone, an adequate record of such notification shall be maintained by the operators notified to document compliance with the requirements of this article. (Code 1995, § 106-155; Ord. No. 1059, § 6, 9-6-1983) Sec. 114-156. - Response to notice of intent to excavate or demolish. (a) Each operator or designated representative notified in accordance with section 114-155 shall, not less than two working days in advance of the proposed excavation or demolition (unless a shorter period is provided by agreement between the person responsible for the excavation or demolition and the operator or designated representative), supply, by use of maps when appropriate, the following information to the person responsible for the excavation or demolition: (1) The appropriate location and description of all of its underground utilities which may be damaged as a result of the excavation or demolition; (2) The location and description of all utility markers indicating the approximate location of the underground utilities; and (3) Any other information which would assist that person in locating and thereby avoiding damage to the underground utilities, including providing adequate temporary markings indicating the approximate location of the underground utility in locations where permanent utility markers do not exist. (b) For purposes of this section, the "approximate location of underground utilities" is defined as a strip of land at least three feet wide but not wider than the width of the utility plus 1.5 feet on either side of the utility. (Code 1995, § 106-156; Ord. No. 1059, § 7, 9-6-1983) Sec. 114-157. - Emergency excavation or demolition. Compliance with the notice requirements of section 114-155 is not required of persons responsible for emergency excavation or demolition to ameliorate an imminent danger to life, health or property; provided, however, that such persons give, as soon as practicable, oral notice of the emergency excavation or demolition to each operator having underground utilities located in the area where such excavation or demolition is to be performed and request emergency assistance from each operator so identified in locating and providing immediate protection to its underground utilities. An imminent danger to life, health or property exists whenever there is a substantial likelihood that loss of life, health or property will result before the procedures under sections 114-155 and 114-156 can be fully complied with. (Code 1995, § 106-157; Ord. No. 1059, § 8, 9-6-1983) Sec. 114-158. - Precautions to avoid damage. In addition to the notification requirements of section 114-155, each person responsible for any excavation or demolition operation designated in section 114-153 shall: (1) Plan the excavation or demolition to avoid damage to or minimize interference with underground utilities in and near the construction area; (2) Maintain a clearance between an underground utility and the cutting edge or point of any mechanized equipment, taking into account the known limit of control of such cutting edge or point, as may be reasonably necessary to avoid damage to such utility; and (3) Provide such support for underground utilities in and near the construction area, including during backfill operations, as may be reasonably necessary for the protection of such utilities. (Code 1995, § 106-158; Ord. No. 1059, § 9, 9-6-1983) Sec. 114-159. - Excavation or demolition damage. (a) Except as provided by subsection (b) of this section, each person responsible for any excavation or demolition operation designated in section 114-153 that results in any damage to an underground utility shall, immediately upon discovery of such damage, notify the operator of such utility of the location and nature of the damage and shall allow the operator reasonable time to accomplish necessary repairs before completing the excavation or demolition in the immediate area of such utility. (b) Each person responsible for any excavation or demolition operations designated in section 114-153 that results in damage to an underground utility permitting the escape of any flammable, toxic, or corrosive gas or liquid shall, immediately upon discovery of such damage, notify the operator, police and fire departments, and take any other action as may be reasonably necessary to protect persons and property and to minimize the hazards until arrival of the operator's personnel or police and fire departments. (Code 1995, § 106-159; Ord. No. 1059, § 10, 9-6-1983) Secs. 114-160—114-175. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - SEWER USE REQUIREMENTS
Sec. 114-176. - General provisions. (a) Purposes and policy. (1) This article sets forth uniform requirements for users of the publicly owned treatment works (POTW) for the city and enables the city to comply with all applicable state and federal laws, including the Clean Water Act (33 USC 1251 et seq.) and the General Pretreatment Regulations (40 CFR 403). The objectives of this article are: a. To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the POTW that will interfere with the operation of the POTW; b. To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the POTW which will pass through the POTW, inadequately treated, into receiving waters or otherwise be incompatible with the POTW; c. To ensure that the quality of the wastewater treatment plant sludge is maintained at a level which allows its use and disposal in compliance with applicable statutes and regulations; d. To protect POTW personnel who may be affected by wastewater and sludge in the course of their employment and to protect the general public; e. To improve the opportunity to recycle and reclaim wastewater and sludge from the POTW. (2) This article shall apply to all users of the POTW. This article authorizes the issuance of wastewater discharge permits; authorizes monitoring, compliance, and enforcement activities; establishes administrative review procedures; requires user reporting; and provides for the setting of fees for the equitable distribution of costs resulting from the program established herein. (b) Administration. Except as otherwise provided herein, the city manager shall administer, implement, and enforce the provisions of this article. Any powers granted to or duties imposed upon the city manager may be delegated by the city manager to other city personnel. The city manager with the express consent of the city council may delegate the implementation of certain provisions of this article to a subcontractor. (c) Definitions. Unless a provision explicitly states otherwise, the following terms and phrases, as used in this article, shall have the meanings hereinafter designated. Act or the Act means the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, also known as the Clean Water Act, as amended, 33 USC 1251 et seq. Applicable pretreatment standards for any specified pollutant, city prohibitive standards, city specific pretreatment standards (local limits), State of Georgia pretreatment standards, or environmental protection agency's (EPA) categorical pretreatment standards (when effective), whichever standard is appropriate or most stringent. Approval authority means the State of Georgia. Authorized representative of the user means: (1) If the user is a corporation: a. The president, secretary, treasurer, or a vice-president of the corporation in charge of a principal business function, or any other person who performs similar policy or decision-making functions for the corporation; or b. The manager of one or more manufacturing, production, or operation facilities, if authority to sign documents has been assigned or delegated to the manager in accordance with corporate procedures; (2) If the user is a partnership or sole proprietorship, a general partner or proprietor, respectively; (3) If the user is a federal, state, or local governmental facility, a director or highest official appointed or designated to oversee the operation and performance of the activities of the government facility, or his/her designee. The individuals described in subsections (1) through (3) of this definition may designate another authorized representative if the authorization is in writing; the authorization specifies the individual or position responsible for the overall operation of the facility from which the discharge originates or having overall responsibility for environmental matters for the company, and the written authorization is submitted to the city. Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedures for five days at 20 degrees Centigrade, usually expressed as a concentration (milligrams per liter (mg/l)). Building sewer means the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal, also called house connection or service connection. Categorical pretreatment standard or categorical standard means any regulation containing pollutant discharge limits promulgated by the U.S. EPA in accordance with Section 307(b) and (c) of the Act (33 USC 1317) which apply to a specific category of users and which appear in 40 CFR Chapter I, Subchapter N, Parts 405—471. Categorical user means a user covered by one of EPA's categorical pretreatment standards. City means the City of Waynesboro or the mayor and city council of Waynesboro. Color means the optical density at the visual wavelength of maximum absorption, relative to distilled water. One hundred percent transmittance is equivalent to zero optical density. Combined sewer means a sewer receiving both surface runoff and sewage. Composite sample means the sample resulting from the combination of individual wastewater samples taken at selected intervals based on an increment of either flow or time. Control authority means the City of Waynesboro. Constituents. The combination of particles or conditions existing in industrial wastes. Cooling water/non-contact cooling water means water used for cooling, which does not come into direct contact with any raw material, intermediate product, waste product, or finished product. Cooling water may be generated from any use, such as air conditioning, heat exchangers, cooling or refrigeration to which the only pollutant added is heat. DHR or health officer means the director of the Georgia Department of Natural Resources, Burke County Board of Health or other person designated by the board of commissioners and their duly appointed assistants. Domestic user (residential user) means any person who contributes, causes, or allows the contribution of wastewater into the city POTW that is of a similar volume and/or chemical make-up as that of a residential dwelling unit. New source means: (1) Any building, structure, facility, or installation from which there is (or may be) a discharge of pollutants, the construction of which commenced after the publication of proposed pretreatment standards under Section 307(c) of the Act which will be applicable to such source if such standards are thereafter promulgated in accordance with that section, provided that: a. The building, structure, facility, or installation is constructed at a site at which no other source is located; b. The production or wastewater generating processes of the building, structure, facility, or installation are substantially independent of an existing source at the same site. In determining whether these are substantially independent, factors such as the extent to which the new facility is integrated with the existing plant, and the extent to which the new facility is engaged in the same general type of activity as the existing source, should be considered. (2) Construction on a site at which an existing source is located results in a modification rather than a new source if the construction does not create a new building, structure, facility, or installation meeting the criteria of subsection (1)b or c of this definition but otherwise alters, replaces, or adds to existing process or production equipment. (3) Construction of a new source as defined under this definition has commenced if the owner or operator has: a. Begun, or caused to begin, as part of a continuous onsite construction program: 1. Any placement, assembly, or installation of facilities or equipment; or 2. Entered into a binding contractual obligation for the purchase of facilities or equipment that has an intended use in its operation within a reasonable time. Options to purchase, or contracts that can be terminated or modified without substantial loss, and contracts for feasibility, engineering, and design studies do not constitute a contractual obligation under this subsection. Any person that buys an existing facility that is discharging non-domestic wastewater will be considered an "existing user" if no significant changes are made in the manufacturing operation. Pass through means a discharge that exits the POTW into waters of the United States in quantities or concentrations which, alone or in conjunction with a discharge or discharges from other sources, is a cause of a violation of any requirement of the city's NPDES and/or other disposal system permit (including an increase in the magnitude or duration of a violation). Permittee means a person or user issued a wastewater discharge permit. Person means any individual, partnership, co-partnership, firm, company, corporation, association, joint stock company, trust, estate, governmental entity, or any other legal entity; or their legal representatives, agents, or assigns. This definition includes all federal, state, or local governmental entities. pH means a measure of the acidity or alkalinity of a substance, expressed in standard units. Pollutant means any dredged spoil, solid waste, incinerator residue, sewage, garbage, sewage sludge, munitions, medical wastes, chemical wastes, biological materials, radioactive materials, heat, wrecked or discharged equipment, rock, sand, cellar dirt, agricultural and industrial wastes, and the characteristics of the wastewater (i.e., pH, temperature, TSS, turbidity, color, BOD, chemical oxygen demand (COD), toxicity, or odor). (18) USC: United States Code. (Ord. No. 2002-02-01, § 1, 8-5-2002) Sec. 114-177. - General requirements. (a) Prohibited discharge standards. (1) General prohibitions. No user shall introduce or cause to be introduced into the POTW any pollutant or wastewater which causes pass through or interference. These general prohibitions apply to all users of the POTW whether or not they are subject to categorical pretreatment standards or any other national, state, or local pretreatment standards or requirements. (2) Specific prohibitions. No user shall introduce or cause to be introduced into the POTW the following pollutants, substances, or wastewater: a. Pollutants which create a fire or explosive hazard in the POTW, including, but not limited to, waste streams with a closed-cup flashpoint of less than 140 degrees Fahrenheit (60 degrees Centigrade) using the test methods specified in 40 CFR 261.21. b. Wastewater having a pH of 5.5 or less or otherwise causing corrosive structural damage to the POTW or equipment. If a continuous pH chart recorder is being used, any occurrence of pH over 9.5 but less than 10.5 for a period of 30 minutes or more per day is prohibited. Any occurrence of pH between 10.5 and 11.0 for more than 15 minutes per day is prohibited. Any pH occurrence over 11.0 is prohibited. If a continuous pH chart recorder is not being used, any occurrence of pH over 9.5 is prohibited. At no time shall any discharge cause the pH of the influent at the POTW head works to go above 9.5 or cause structural damage. c. Solid or viscous substances in amounts which will cause obstruction of the flow in the POTW resulting in interference, but in no case solids greater than one half-inch or 256 centimeters in any dimension. d. Pollutants, including oxygen-demanding pollutants (BOD, etc.), released in a discharge at a flow rate and/or pollutant concentration which, either singly or by interaction with other pollutants, will cause interference with the POTW. e.
